message.content:
We first note that the “Initial” transactions (the ones with id beginning with “Initial…”) do not list any AR‐related amounts so we take the starting AR balance as zero.

Then we scan the “Sale” transactions – only those that have their “receive_method” value marked as “Account Receviable” (spelling preserved as in the data) contribute to the balance sheet “Accounts Receivable” amount. (That is, because cash‐sales – even if “Unpaid” are not part of AR if the customer has already paid by cash. In our ledger the decisions on which sale contributes to AR are made by the “receive_method” field.)

Below we list the sale transactions that hit AR (with the “after_tax_amount” as the posted amount):

1. Sale20240103005: 10798.85  
2. Sale20240104007: 11847.10  
3. Sale20240104008: 9854.18  
4. Sale20240104009: 2074.51  
5. Sale20240111017: 55649.81  
6. Sale20240112018: 278523.24  
7. Sale20240112019: 55873.75

19. Sale20240119036: 183731.52  
20. Sale20240122040: 40151.80  
21. Sale20240124044: 283651.19  
22. Sale20240124045: 2063.88  
23. Sale20240126050: 55796.80  
24. Sale20240126052: 1966.11  
25. Sale20240127055: 2021.03  
26. Sale20240131060: 45049.57  
27. Sale20240203068: 214382.65  
28. Sale20240203069: 1821.26  
29. Sale20240205072: 9164.30  
30. Sale20240205073: 10586.27  

If you add up these amounts (step‐by‐step the subtotals coming to a final total of 1,959,834.90), you get the ending “Accounts Receivable” balance.

Thus the result is:

Initial AR value = 0.00  
Final AR value = 1,959,834.90

Below is the answer in the required json format.

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Accounts Receivable Initial Value": "0.00", "Accounts Receivable End Value": "1959834.90"}}
```
